div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
IT may be, some Rhetoric ••
Praelector holdes it enquirable for the Title, as professing too much of affectation thereunto. Nor do I blame him, when, conferring the importance therof with our impotence, he deprehend not a reason in the very front, or first face of my Booke. It shall suffice, for thy better satisfaction, I was most inward with mine owne defects: which I studied to preserue from seuerer exposition, as thus: If any challenge me for dismembring a good history, which might better haue beene continuated from the beginning, it was not I, but Passion. If, that my Introduction be somewhat too prolix, in respect of the maine sub • ect proposed. All this was of Passion, that once enlargde, is hardly called in and restrained. If that in many of these Plants, I obserue no strict methode or time; I aunswere still, it was of Passion: One that neuer speakes in numbers, neuer beginnes with a Quande • uidem, or Quemadmodum, one that respectes not the preparatiue complement of hemming or spitting, the authenti • ue stroaking of the beard, or your demure winking. Briefly, one of the most licentious, irregular, and vnformall Libertines of this Age, and notwithstanding as cur • ant for excusable, as the loosers language, or some preuaricator in a learned assembly. From hence I was aduised to assume his sh • pe, as a most spatious protection, which the rather I made personate in the Poet, as well for suggestion of his office, which ought to bee most conuersant in P • ssion out of the abuses of these times, as for conciliation of our true Diuines, whome I onely admire, and not of arrogance, as being sensible of any thing in m • e, which might maintaine such profest impo • tance. He that vrgeth 〈◊〉 further herein, giues me cause, if vnlearned, to suspect his iudgement; if learned, his seueritie.
